sec.title: Background:
sec.p: In China, laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair (LIHR) under the day surgery mode (DSM) has developed rapidly as an important surgical method for inguinal hernia repair, and it has unique advantages in many aspects. Compared with inpatient surgery mode (ISM), there are some differences in intraoperative and postoperative related indicators, hospitalization costs, and patient satisfaction. Many studies have shown that LIHR in DSM can significantly shorten hospital stay, effectively reduce hospitalization costs, and improve patient satisfaction. Accordingly, this study aimed to compare the differences in intraoperative and postoperative related indicators, hospitalization costs, and patient satisfaction of LIHR between DSM and ISM in China.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: The PubMed/Medline, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, and Wan Fang databases were searched for randomized controlled trials, cohort studies from the establishment of the database to July 1, 2022. Odds ratio (OR), mean difference, standardized mean difference (SMD), and 95% confidence interval were selected as the effect scale indices for the evaluation of the difference in hospitalization costs, hospital stay, operation time, recovery time, complications, and patient satisfaction. All of these were compared using RevMan 5.3 Software (The Cochrane Collaboration, Copenhagen, Denmark).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Nine studies involving 1176 patients, 590 in the DSM group and 586 in the ISM group, were included. The hospital stay (d) (SMD = −7.27, 95% confidence interval, CI: −8.68 to −5.87, P < .001), hospitalization costs (SMD = −7.89, 95% CI: −10.25 to −5.53, P < .001) in DSM group were significantly lower than the ISM group. Additionally, the patient dissatisfaction (OR = 0.05, 95% CI: 0.01–0.17, P < .001) in DSM group was significantly lower than the ISM group. Nevertheless, no significant differences were found in the operation time (minute) (mean difference = −0.32, 95% CI: −1.78 to 1.14, P = .67), recovery time (h) (SMD = −3.27, 95% CI: −6.95 to 0.41, P = .08), and postoperative complications (OR = 0.80, 95% CI: 0.47–1.36, P = .41) between the 2 groups.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: In China, compared with ISM, LIHR under DSM can significantly shorten hospital stay, greatly reduce hospitalization costs, and significantly improve patient satisfaction. There were no significant differences in operation time, recovery time and postoperative complications.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Inguinal hernia is a common disease worldwide, lifetime occurrence of groin hernia-viscera or adipose tissue protrusions through the inguinal or femoral canal-is 27% to 43% in men and 3% to 6% in women,[1] the only cure is surgery.[2] Worldwide, more than 20 million patients undergo groin hernia repair annually.[3] In China, approximately 2 million hernia patients require surgery each year.[4] The Lancet reported in 2017 and 2018 an evaluation of the Medical Accessibility and Treatment Quality Index for inguinal hernia in adults in China (scores of 99 and 100, respectively),[5,6] surpassing many developed countries.

The concept of day surgery (Ambulatory Surgery/Day Surgery) was first proposed by Dr Nicoll in England. With the establishment of The International Association of Ambulatory Surgery (IAAS), ambulatory surgery has developed into a more mature form of surgical management model. The International Association for Ambulatory Surgery (IAAS) recommends that ambulatory surgery be defined as a patient who completes the surgery or procedure within 1 working day and is discharged from the hospital, excluding surgery or procedures performed in clinics or outpatient clinics. The definition of day surgery in China is basically the same, but a supplementary explanation is made on this basis: for patients with delayed hospitalization for day surgery, the maximum length of hospitalization shall not exceed 48 hours.[7] Day surgery has the advantages of shortening the average length of hospital stay, reducing hospitalization costs, and accelerating patient recovery, and can effectively improve the utilization of medical resources.[8,9]In the United States, there were more than 4000 independent day surgery centers in 2004, and now covering almost all surgical departments.[10] In China, the development of day surgery is significantly later than that in Western countries. After more than 10 years of development, it has shown its advantages in shortening the average hospital stay, reducing medical expenses, accelerating patient recovery, and improving the utilization rate of medical resources.

Since the first report of day surgery for inguinal hernias in 1955,[11] the open approach inguinal hernia repair under day surgery mode (DSM) has proven to be safe, feasible and cost-effective, and many countries have made open approach inguinal hernia repair routine;[12] In China, DSM is becoming more and more popular. According to statistics, the number of day surgery for inguinal hernia performed every year has taken the second place in all day surgery diseases.[13]

Studies have shown that simple inguinal hernias can be performed in a DSM, whether open surgery or laparoscopic surgery.[14,15] The advantages of laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair (LIHR) over open hernia repair seem to be more suitable for the DSM. Since 1993, transabdominal preperitoneal hernia repair (TAPP) and total extraperitoneal hernia repair (TEP) have been regarded as the gold standard procedures for LIHR, and the number has increased rapidly year by year. In the past 10 years, LIHR surgery has developed rapidly in China, and the amount of surgery has accounted for 10% to 40% of tension-free inguinal hernia repair,[16]it has the advantages of less postoperative pain, faster postoperative recovery, and shorter hospital stay.[17,18]

Although LIHR has the above advantages, due to China’s vast territory and large regional differences, the development level of day surgery technology and management is unbalanced, and patient concepts, medical policies, and process management also affect the development of day surgery. In China, the advantages of LIHR under the DSM still lack strong support from large-scale, multi center research conclusions. Therefore, this study searched and included relevant studies to systematically evaluate the intraoperative and postoperative efficacy of LIHR under DSM and inpatient surgery mode (ISM) in China, in order to seek relatively objective and accurate conclusions. We hope to provide a favorable evidence-based medical basis for clinical treatment.

sec.title: 2.1. Search strategy
sec.p: The PubMed/Medline, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, and Wanfang databases were searched for Chinese studies published from their inception to July 1, 2022, comparing DSM versus ISM for LIHR. The search was performed for studies that included in their Title or Abstract the following search terms: day surgery, inpatient surgery, inguinal hernia, total extraperitoneal hernia repair, TEP, transabdominal preperitoneal, TAPP, only in English and Chinese.
This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Affiliated Hospital of the North Sichuan Medical College.

sec.title: 2.2. Inclusion and exclusion criteria
sec.p: The following inclusion criteria were applied: First, the original study must have compared LIHR patients in China who underwent DSM or ISM. Second, the original study types included randomized controlled trials, and cohort studies. Third, at least one of the following indicators should be considered: operation time, recovery time, postoperative complications, hospital stay, hospitalization costs, and patient satisfaction. The exclusion criteria were as follows: retrospective studies, review articles, case reports, abstracts, editorials, letters to the editor, studies with insufficient data on outcome measures, and incomplete documents or documents with incomplete data.

sec.title: 2.3. Data extraction
sec.p: Original data, including the first author, year of publication, type of procedure, sample size, age, sex, and outcome, were independently extracted from the articles by 2 authors and keyed them in a standardized form. Conflicts in data abstraction were resolved by referring to the original article.

sec.title: 2.4. Quality assessment
sec.p: The quality of the literature was independently assessed by the authors, in accordance with the Cochrane Collaboration Handbook. The assessment tools included the following criteria: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of participants and personnel, blinding of the assessment results, incomplete data of the results, selective reporting, and other sources of bias. A controversial article was selected after discussion with a third researcher.

sec.title: 2.5. Statistical analysis
sec.p: Review Manager version 5.3 (The Cochrane Collaboration, Copenhagen, Denmark) was used to perform a meta-analysis. Odds ratio (OR), mean difference, standardized mean difference (SMD), and 95% confidence interval were selected as the effect scale indicators. The heterogeneity of each study was evaluated using the Cochrane Q test and I2 test; if case I2 ≥ 50%, heterogeneity appeared between studies. A random-effects model was used in cases of significant heterogeneity. Otherwise, a fixed-effects model was used. This study conducted a sensitivity analysis by excluding studies 1 by 1, and the stability of the results of I2 and the changes in the combined effect size after excluding studies were analyzed.

sec.title: 3.1. Basic information of the included studies
sec.p: A total of 802 original studies were obtained by searching the databases. A total of 390 duplicate, irrelevant, and unqualified studies were excluded after reading the texts and abstracts, and the remaining 37 studies satisfied the research topic. Furthermore, 28 studies were excluded because of improper grouping or different outcomes. A detailed flowchart of the selection process is presented in Figure 1.

Finally, 9 studies[19–27] were identified, including 5,[20,22,25–27] and 4 cohort studies.[19,21,23,24] A total of 1176 patients were included, including 590 in DSM group and 586 in ISM group. The baseline data are shown in Table 1.

sec.title: 3.2. Length of hospital stay
sec.p: Nine studies[19–27] provided data regarding the length of hospital stay (d) with a total of 1176 cases, covering 590 cases in the DSM group and 586 in the ISM group. Heterogeneity analysis showed obvious heterogeneity among the results of each study (P < .001, I2 = 100%), and the random-effects model was adopted. The length of hospital stay of the DSM group was shorten to that of the ISM group (SMD = −7.27, 95% confidence interval, CI: −8.68 to 5.87, P < .001) (Fig. 2). Sensitivity analysis was performed after removing the articles individually, and neither heterogeneity nor forest plot changed significantly, indicating that the meta-analysis results were stable and reliable.

caption.p: Forest plot of comparison on hospital stay: DSM vs ISM. DSM = day surgery mode, ISM = inpatient surgery mode.

sec.title: 3.3. Hospitalization costs
sec.p: Seven studies[19–22,24,26,27] provided data regarding the hospitalization costs (CNY) with a total of 608 cases, covering 304 cases in the DSM group and 304 in the ISM group. Heterogeneity analysis showed heterogeneity among the results of each study (P < .001, I2 = 99%), and the random-effects model was adopted. The hospitalization costs of the DSM group were significantly lower than that of the ISM group (SMD = −7.89, 95% CI: −10.25 to 5.53, P < .001) (Fig. 3). Sensitivity analysis indicating that the meta-analysis results were stable and reliable.

caption.p: Forest plot of comparison on hospitalization costs: DSM vs ISM. DSM = day surgery mode, ISM = inpatient surgery mode.

sec.title: 3.4. Operation time
sec.p: Six studies[19,20,22–25] provided data regarding the operation time (minute) with a total of 906 cases, covering 455 cases in the DSM group and 451 in the ISM group. Heterogeneity analysis showed no obvious heterogeneity among the results of each study (P = .91, I2 = 0%), and the fixed-effects model was adopted. The operation time of the DSM group was similar to that of the ISM group (mean difference = −0.32, 95% CI: −1.78 to 1.14, P = .67) (Fig. 4). Sensitivity analysis indicating that the meta-analysis results were stable and reliable.

caption.p: Forest plot of comparison on operation time: DSM vs ISM. DSM = day surgery mode, ISM = inpatient surgery mode.

sec.title: 3.5. Postoperative complications
sec.p: Eight studies[19,20,22–27] provided data regarding the postoperative complications with a total of 1116 cases, covering 560 cases in the DSM group and 556 in the ISM group. Heterogeneity analysis showed no obvious heterogeneity among the results of each study (P = .92, I2 = 0%), and the fixed-effects model was adopted. The complications of the DSM group were similar to that of the ISM group (OR = 0.80, 95% CI: 0.47–1.36, P = .41) (Fig. 5). Sensitivity analysis indicating that the meta-analysis results were stable and reliable.

caption.p: Forest plot of comparison on complications: DSM vs ISM. DSM = day surgery mode, ISM = inpatient surgery mode.

sec.title: 3.6. Recovery time
sec.p: Three studies[20,22,24] provided data regarding the recovery time (hours) with a total of 276 cases, covering 138 cases in the DSM group and 138 in the ISM group. Heterogeneity analysis showed obvious heterogeneity among the results of each study (P < .001, I2 = 94%), and the random-effects model was adopted. The recovery time of the DSM group were similar to that of the ISM group (SMD = −3.27, 95% CI: −6.95 to 0.41, P = .08) (Fig. 6). Sensitivity analysis indicating that the meta-analysis results were stable and reliable.

caption.p: Forest plot of comparison on recovery time: DSM vs ISM. DSM = day surgery mode, ISM = inpatient surgery mode.

sec.title: 3.7. Patient satisfaction
sec.p: Three studies[22,26,27] provided data regarding the patient satisfaction with a total of 290 cases, covering 145 cases in the DSM group and 145 in the ISM group. Heterogeneity analysis showed no obvious heterogeneity among the results of each study (P = .42, I2 = 0%), and the fixed-effects model was adopted. The patient dissatisfaction of the DSM group was lower than that of the ISM group (1.38% vs 26.89%) (OR = 0.05, 95% CI: 0.01–0.17, P < .001) (Fig. 7). Sensitivity analysis indicating that the meta-analysis results were stable and reliable.

caption.p: Forest plot of comparison on patient dissatisfaction: DSM vs ISM. DSM = day surgery mode, ISM = inpatient surgery mode.

sec.title: 3.8. Risk of bias in included studies
sec.p: No obvious publication bias can be observed from the bias analysis chart. All the included literatures were analyzed. The risk of bias of the included studies is shown in Figure 8.

sec.title: 4. Discussion
sec.p: This study compared the differences in LIHR (TAPP, TEP) surgery-related indicators, hospital stay, treatment costs, and patient satisfaction between DSM and ISM in China. A total of 1176 patients were included in the study, of which 590 were in DSM group and 586 were ISM group. The results showed that there were significant differences between the 2 groups in hospital stay, hospitalization costs, and patient satisfaction. However, no significant difference was found in operation time, recovery time, and postoperative complications.

Inguinal hernia repair in DSM is increasingly becoming an important part of day surgery because of its standardized surgical methods, rapid recovery, and intuitive effects, and its application scope and extent are expanding. In the past, the open approach under local anesthesia was mostly used for day surgery inguinal hernia repair. However, for some special patients, such as obesity, bilateral inguinal hernia, and patients with open postoperative recurrence, LIHR under general anesthesia has the greater advantage.[3,28] It has the characteristics of “posterior approach,” “observability” and “operation under direct vision” which are not available in open surgery. Studies have shown that LIHR in DSM can further reduce postoperative pain and chronic postoperative pain, shorten the recovery time, and reduce the omission of occult hernias.[29,30]

As mentioned above, due to China’s vast territory and large regional differences, the development level of day surgery technology and management is unbalanced, and patient concepts, medical policies, and process management also affect the development of day surgery. Therefore, in China, the advantages of LIHR in DSM still lack strong support from large-scale, multi center research conclusions. In addition, most previous studies in China have shortcomings such as small sample size, inconsistent conclusions, and low reliability, and are not convincing. In view of the above reasons, in order to improve the credibility of the conclusions and obtain more objective conclusions, we formulated and improved the inclusion criteria, focusing on the inclusion of randomized controlled studies and cohort studies were included, and the number of included studies was greater, the data were updated, the quality was higher, and the grouping was more scientific. This study strictly screened the literature according to the inclusion and exclusion indicators, and finally included 9 literatures, and processed the relevant data through the Meta analysis software. The results showed that the LIHR operation in the DSM has obvious advantages in China. Compared with the ISM, the LIHR in the DSM can significantly shorten the hospital stay, greatly reduce the hospitalization costs, and improve patient satisfaction, without increasing the operation time, recovery time, and postoperative complications.

The main goal of the DSM is to shorten the treatment cycle of patients. By optimizing the perioperative process, the treatment cycle can be greatly shortened. Most studies in China and abroad show that day surgery performed in multiple disciplines including gynecology, ophthalmology, and hepatobiliary surgery can significantly shorten the length of hospital stay. Although some studies in China have shown that LIHR under the DSM can save operation time, there is still a lack of systematic review of related studies. Therefore, this study collects relevant high-quality literatures in China and conducts a systematic review to make up for the lack of research in this field. The results of this study showed that: in China, LIHR under the DSM can significantly shorten the hospital stay of patients, which achieved the original intention of establishing the DSM.

The most immediate benefit of shortening the length of hospital stay is the reduction in hospital costs. The literature included in this study all suggest that the treatment cost of LIHR in the DSM is lower than that in the ISM, and the results of the meta-analysis support this conclusion. Although compared with foreign countries, there are large regional differences in China, and there are also corresponding differences in surgical techniques, management levels, patient concepts, medical policies, and process management; however, the advantages of LIHR under the DSM are still effective, it can effectively reduce the cost of treatment.

On the basis of significantly shortening the length of hospital stay and reducing the cost of treatment, LIHR in the DSM does not sacrifice other indicators. From the results of the meta-analysis, there were no significant differences in the operation time, recovery time, and postoperative complications between the DSM and the ISM. At the same time, we also counted the readmission rate of the included studies, among which 6 studies[20,22–25,27] had no readmission cases during the follow-up period, and 3 studies[19,21,26] did not mention the readmission rate, indicating that there was no significant difference in readmission rate between DSM and ISM. In contrast to the above results, the analysis of patient satisfaction showed that LIHR in the DSM can significantly improve patient satisfaction. In the development of modern medicine, patient satisfaction is one of the most important goals other than the pursuit of the best curative effect and the least complications, and the LIHR in the DSM has successfully achieved this goal and played a role in its obvious advantages.

However, our study also has certain limitations: Firstly, the number of included articles is small; Secondly, the types and severity of inguinal hernias are inconsistent, and between different studies There are some differences in the surgical skills of surgeons and the management of patients, which may lead to implementation bias and some degree of heterogeneity; Thirdly, because the basic data of the included studies could not fully meet the needs, we failed to conduct a subgroup analysis of patients including different ages, different hernia types and so on, which needs to be further improved in subsequent studies.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: Meta-analysis results show that LIHR in the DSM, as an emerging surgical mode, it has achieved quite good curative effect in China. It has indeed shortened the hospital stay, reduced the treatment cost, and improved the satisfaction of the patients, and it is not affected in terms of operation time, recovery time, and postoperative complications. In conclusion, this surgical model is safe and feasible, and patients can benefit significantly, and it is worthy of further popularization in China. At the same time, it also reminds us: should we accelerate the promotion of this surgical model in more developing countries?. This is an issue that deserves to be put on the agenda early. Of course, well-designed, large-scale and multi center studies are needed to further confirm the results of this study.
